body:
The problem is that pytest-pythonpath plugin name is `pythonpath`, and the new pytest builtin plugin is also called `pythonpath`. Since the builtin `pythonpath` plugin is registered first, the `pytest-pythonpath` plugin gets ignored.

This was not intentional. We will need to change the builtin plugin's name, probably to `python_path`. That's not as nice, but what can you do.

Another possible solution would perhaps be to add support for `python_paths` in the core, but deprecate it immediately. That way, it's not a silent failure, but people know that they could get rid of the plugin.

@The-Compiler I like this idea. IIRC there are some minor behavior differences, I will need to review them but if they don't matter then I think we should do it (or make `python_paths` behave compatibly).
I don't like the idea of having two names for the same thing in the long run - that sounds like a recipe for confusion.

issue.title: pythonpath: make it compatible with pytest-pythonpath until pytest 8

labels.name: needs backport
labels.description: applied to PRs, indicates that it should be ported to the current bug-fix branch

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

body:
I can confirm we're having similar issue in our project. Running pytest test command returns an error:
`ImportError: No module named 'tests.settings'`

We also have tests in a separate directory and pinning pytest version to <7.0 fixes the issue temporary.

>  We will need to change the builtin plugin's name, probably to python_path. That's not as nice, but what can you do.

Just to give my 2 cents, I would rather we go with that route: this will fix the problem immediately, without creating future churn for us, and without introducing confusion (like duplicated names). Of course this type of problem (introducing a new core plugin with the same name of an external plugin by accident) might happen again in the future, but regardless this type of problem needs to be fixed/considered on a case-by-case basis.

(Sorry for just jumping in now, after #9640 was already proposed)

issue.title: 7.0.0 regression: Existence of conftest.py messes up package discovery with importlib + pythonpath mode (ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'tests.<test-packages>')

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: problem that needs to be addressed

labels.name: type: regression
labels.description: indicates a problem that was introduced in a release which was working previously

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
Consider the following demo project:

**`setup.cfg`**
```ini
# The idea is to use `pythonpath = .` to enable imports from the `tests` folder
# like `import tests.<subpackages>`.
# Note that all involved directories have proper __init__.py, and importing e.g.
# `import tests.subpath.helper` works from a Python REPL.
[tool:pytest]
pythonpath = .
addopts =
    --import-mode importlib
```

**`tests/__init__.py`**
```python
# just empty
```

**`tests/conftest.py`** (existence of this file breaks package discovery)
```python
# just empty
```

**`tests/subpath/__init__.py`**
```python
# just empty
```

**`tests/subpath/helper.py`**
```python
# just empty
```

**`tests/subpath/test_something.py`**
```python
import tests.subpath.helper


def test_something():
    assert True
```

pytest (version 7.0.0) errors with:

```
______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________ ERROR collecting tests/subpath/test_something.py _______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________
ImportError while importing test module '/tmp/demo_project/tests/subpath/test_something.py'.
Hint: make sure your test modules/packages have valid Python names.
Traceback:
tests/subpath/test_something.py:1: in <module>
    import tests.subpath.helper
E   ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'tests.subpath'; 'tests' is not a package
=========================================================================================================================================================== short test summary info ===========================================================================================================================================================
ERROR tests/subpath/test_something.py
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Interrupted: 1 error during collection !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
============================================================================================================================================================== 1 error in 0.08s ===============================================================================================================================================================
```

What's particularly surprising: The example works, when renaming the `conftest.py` to e.g. `conftest2.py`. I.e., it seems that the existence of the `conftest.py` implies that it is no longer possible to import from `tests`. Imports like this used to work with pre 7 pytest versions in `importlib` mode despite the existence of a `conftest.py`.

body:
I think the deprecations are not too bad because they also serve to tell people "hey you don't need pytest-pythonpath any more".

I believe the logging plugin was once separate. Do you remember how its promotion was handled and if it went well?

> I think the deprecations are not too bad because they also serve to tell people "hey you don't need pytest-pythonpath any more".

True, but not sure it is worth the hassle on our side, and who knows if the author of that plugin wants to add further capabilities in the future (but I concede that's unlikely)? The deprecation approach basically "kills" the plugin.  

> Do you remember how its promotion was handled and if it went well?

IIRC we issued a warning if it was installed, but we also released a new pytest-logging with an "empty" package so there wasn't conflicts. In that case it was a concerted effort to integrate them, which is not the same situation with `pytest-pythonpath`.
